revision.text:
{{No footnotes|date=March 2013}}
The '''International Geographical Union''' ('''IGU'''; {{lang-fr|'''Union Géographique Internationale'''}}, '''UGI''') is an international [[geography|geographical]] society. The first International Geographical Congress was held in [[Antwerp]] in 1871. Subsequent meetings led to the establishment of the permanent organization in [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]], in 1922.
The International Geographical Union adheres to the [[International Council for Science]] (ICSU) and the [[International Social Science Council]] (ISSC), which it recognizes as coordinating bodies for the international organization of science.
== Objectives == The IGU has seven objectives or aims:
# to promote the study of geographical problems; # to initiate and co-ordinate geographical research requiring international co-operation and to promote its scientific discussion and publication; # to provide for the participation of geographers in the work of relevant international organizations; # to facilitate the collection and diffusion of geographical data and documentation in and between all member countries; # to promote International Geographical Congresses, regional conferences and specialized symposia related to the objectives of the Union; # to participate in any other appropriate form of international co-operation with the object of advancing the study and application of geography; # to promote international standardization or compatibility of methods, nomenclature, and symbols employed in geography.
== Senior Officers == The following lists contain the Senior Officers of the IGU from 1922 to present:
=== Presidents === * '''2016–present Yukio Himiyama, [[Japan]] * 2012–16 Vladimir Aleksandrovich Kolosov, [[Russia|Russian Federation]] * 2008–12 [[Ronald F. Abler|Ronald Francis Abler]], [[United States]] * 2006–08 José Palacio-Prieto, [[Mexico]], acting * 2004–06 Adalberto Vallega, [[Italy]], died in office * 2000–04 [[Anne Buttimer]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] * 1996–2000 Bruno Messerli, [[Switzerland]] * 1992–96 Herman Th. Verstappen, [[Netherlands]] * 1988–92 Roland J. Fuchs, [[United States]] * 1984–88 Peter Scott, [[Australia]] * 1980–84 [[Akin Mabogunje|Akin L. Mabogunje]], [[Nigeria]] * 1976–80 [[Michael John Wise|Michael J. Wise]], [[United Kingdom]] * 1972–76 Jean Dresch, [[France]] * 1968–72 [[Stanisław Leszczycki]], [[Poland]] * 1964–68 [[Shiba P. Chatterjee]], [[India]] * 1960–64 [[Carl Troll]], [[Germany]] * 1956–60 [[Hans Wilhelmsson Ahlmann]], [[Sweden]] * 1952–56 [[Laurence Dudley Stamp|L. Dudley Stamp]], [[United Kingdom]] * 1949–52 [[George B. Cressey]], [[United States]] * 1938–49 [[Emmanuel de Martonne]], [[France]] * 1934–38 Sir [[Charles Close]], [[United Kingdom]] * 1931–34 [[Isaiah Bowman]], [[United States]] * 1928–31 General Robert Bourgeois, [[France]] * 1924–28 General Nicola Vacchelli, [[Italy]] * 1922–24 Prince [[Roland Bonaparte]], [[France]]
=== Secretaries-General and Treasurers === * '''2010–present Michael Meadows, [[South Africa]] * 2008–10 Yu Woo-ik, [[South Korea]] * 2000–08 [[Ronald F. Abler|Ronald Francis Abler]], [[United States]] * 1992–2000 Eckart Ehlers, [[Germany]] * 1984–92 Leszek A. Kosiński, [[Canada]] * 1976–84 Walther Manshard, [[Germany]] * 1968–76 [[Chauncy Harris|Chauncy D. Harris]], [[United States]] * 1956–68 Hans Boesch, [[Switzerland]] * 1949–56 George H. T. Kimble, [[Canada]] * 1938–49 Paul Michotte + Marguerite-Alice Lefèvre, [[Belgium]] * 1931–38 Emmanuel de Martonne, [[France]] * 1928–31 Filippo de Filippi, [[Italy]] * 1922–28 Sir Charles Close, [[United Kingdom]]
== Commissions and Task Forces == The IGU is organized into a number of commissions and task forces that deal with specific topics<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://igu-online.org/organization/commissions/|title=Commissions|work=IGU Online|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en-US}}</ref>.
The commission topics include e.g. specific approaches (e.g. Applied Geography), topics (e.g. Climatology, Health and Environment), methods (e.g. Geographical Information Science), and spatial examples (e.g. Mediterranean Basin). There are also commissions for the [[International Geography Olympiad|International Olympiad]] and Geographical Education.
The two task forces are "Young and Early-Career Geographers" and "Centennial and Sesquicentennial".
=== IGU-CGE === The IGU-CGE (Commission on Geographical Education) focuses on geography education. It is currently headed by co-chairs Clare Brooks (UK) and Chew-Hung Chang (Singapore)<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.igu-cge.org/steering-committee/|title=People - IGU CGE|work=IGU CGE|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en-US}}</ref>.
It publishes the IRGEE journal and organizes yearly conferences<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.igu-cge.org/|title=Home - IGU CGE|website=IGU CGE|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-28}}</ref>. The "International Charter on Geographical Education" constitutes an international agreement on different aspects with global impacts. The 2016 charter features e.g. important geography education research questions and policy recommendations<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.igu-cge.org/2016-charter/|title=2016 Charter - IGU CGE|work=IGU CGE|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en-US}}</ref>. In the 1992 charter there is also information on geographic questions, key concepts, approaches and the selection of spatial examples<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.igu-cge.org/1992-charter/|title=1992 Charter - IGU CGE|work=IGU CGE|access-date=2018-06-28|language=en-US}}</ref>.
== References == {{reflist}} * Kish, George (1992) "International Geographical Union: A Brief History" ''GeoJournal'' 26, No. 2:224-228 ISSN 0343-2521 * Marie-Claire Robic, Anne-Marie Briend, Mechtild Rössler (eds.) (1996) ''Geographers to the world. The International Geographical Union and the International Geographical Congress'' Paris: L'Harmattan {{ISBN|9782738445735}} * Dunbar, Gary S. (2001) [https://books.google.com/books?id=cdKdjqnbnRgC&pg=PA36 ''Geography: Discipline, Profession and Subject since 1870: An International Survey''] Kluwer Academic Publishers {{ISBN|1-4020-0019-7}} pg 36 * Lidstone, John; Williams, Michael (2006) [https://books.google.com/books?id=w9UQmnHApF0C&pg=PA39 ''Geographical Education in a Changing World: Past Experience, Current Trends and Future Challenges''] Springer {{ISBN|978-1-4020-4806-7}} pg 39 * International Geographical Union (IGU) * Royal Irish Academy (RIA)
== External links == * [http://www.igu-online.org/ International Geographical Union / Union Géographique Internationale] * [http://igu.org.ru/en/ International Geographical Union - Russian National Committee]
{{International Council for Science}}
{{Authority control}}
[[Category:Geographic societies]] [[Category:International organisations based in Belgium]] [[Category:Members of the International Council for Science]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 5 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2) ([[User:Balon Greyjoy|Balon Greyjoy]])
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Geodesy}} [[Image:ITM example 2007-06-05.jpg|right|300px|thumb|ITM coordinates on an OSi map from 2006. In this example the easting and the northing are separated by a comma.]] [[Image:ITM map of Ireland.svg|right|300px|thumb|An illustration of ITM coordinates over a map of Ireland. Eastings are on the top/bottom. Northings are on the right/left.]] '''Irish Transverse Mercator''' ('''ITM''') is the [[geographic coordinate system]] for Ireland. It was implemented jointly by the [[Ordnance Survey Ireland]] (OSi) and the [[Ordnance Survey of Northern Ireland]] (OSNI) in 2001. The name is derived from the [[Transverse Mercator]] projection it uses and the fact that it is optimised for the island of Ireland.
==History== The older [[Irish grid reference system]] required GPS measurements to be "translated" (using [[Coordinate system#Transformations|co-ordinate transformations]]). The more precise the GPS measurements were, the more the translation process introduced inaccuracies.
While the existing [[Universal Transverse Mercator|UTM]] co-ordinate system partly fulfilled the requirement for direct GPS compatibility it had some drawbacks, including varying levels of distortion across the island due to the central meridian being at the west coast of Ireland.
The new system needed to satisfy various criteria: GPS compatibility, map distortion for the whole island of Ireland had to be minimal, it was to be [[Map projection#Conformal|conformal]] and backward compatible with existing mapping. A customised Transverse Mercator projection was chosen.
ITM and the older more established Irish Grid will (initially at least) be used in parallel. As a result ITM coordinates had to be obviously different so users would not confuse the two. This was done by shifting the ITM false origin further into the Atlantic and thereby creating substantially different co-ordinate numbers for any given location.
While OSi and OSNI intend to supply map information in the older Irish Grid format into the future, the Irish Institution of Surveyors has recommended that ITM be adopted as soon as possible as the preferred official co-ordinate system for Ireland.
==Examples==
An ITM co-ordinate is generally given as a pair of two six-digit numbers (excluding any digits behind a [[decimal point]] which may be used in very precise surveying). The first number is always the [[easting]] and the second is the [[northing]]. The easting and northing are in metres from the false [[Origin (mathematics)|origin]].
The ITM co-ordinate for the [[Spire of Dublin]] on [[O'Connell Street]] is:
:715830, 734697
The first figure is the easting and means that the location is 715,830 metres east from the false origin (along the [[X axis]]). The second figure is the northing and puts the location 734,697 metres north of the false origin (along the [[Y axis]])
The equivalent Irish Grid co-ordinate for the same location is:
:315904, 234671
The Spire of Dublin example provides a [[Position fixing|fix]] for a location that is accurate to 1 metre. With ITM it is possible to give a more accurate co-ordinate for a given location by using a decimal point after the initial six figure easting and northing.
The ITM co-ordinate for the passive GPS station at the OSi office is:
:E 709885.081m, N 736167.699m
This ITM co-ordinate has three digits behind the decimal point which gives a fix for a location with millimetre accuracy. Also notice how the easting in this example is indicated with an “E” and likewise an “N” for the northing. The fact that the co-ordinate is in metres is indicated by the lowercase m.
With ITM there is no provision for using [[Myriad (unit of area)|myriad]] letters and truncated coordinates as there is with the Irish Grid. Every co-ordinate must be given with at least a six digit easting and northing from the false origin.
==Comparison of ITM, Irish Grid and UTM== {| class="wikitable" ! ! '''''ITM''''' ! '''''Irish Grid''''' !''''' UTM 29''''' |- | '''''[[Reference ellipsoid]]:''''' | [[GRS80]] | Airy Modified | GRS80 |- | '''''Central Meridian:''''' | 8° West | 8° West | 9° West |- | '''''[[Scale (map)|Scale]] on Central Meridian:''''' | 0.999 820 | 1.000 035 | 0.999 600 |- | '''''True Origin:''''' | 53° 30' North; 8° West | 53° 30' North; 8° West | 0° 00' North; 9° West |- | '''''False Origin:''''' | 600,000m West; 750,000m South | 200,000m West; 250,000m South | 500,000m West; 0m South |- | '''''[[Ordnance Datum|Vertical Datum]]:''''' | [[Malin Head]] | Malin Head | ? |- | '''''[[EPSG]] Code:''''' | 2157 | 29902 | 32629 |}
==See also== * [[GRS80]] * [[ETRS89]]

revision.comment: Disambiguating links to [[British Mandate of Palestine]] (link changed to [[British Mandate for Palestine (legal instrument)]]; link changed to [[British Mandate for Palestine (legal instrument)]]) using [[User:Qwertyytrewqqwerty/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
{{Time zones of the Middle East}} {{Time zones of Israel}} [[File:Begin CEST Transparent.png|thumb|150px|When IDT starts, clocks advance from 02:00 to 03:00.]] [[File:End CEST in Israel.svg|thumb|150px|When IDT ends, clocks retreat from 02:00 to 01:00.]] '''Israel Summer Time''' ({{lang-he|שעון קיץ}} ''{{transl|he|sha'on kayits }}'' "Summer Clock"), also in English, '''Israel Daylight Time''' ('''IDT''') is the practice in [[Israel]] by which clocks are advanced by one hour, beginning on the Friday before the last Sunday of March, and ending on the last Sunday of October.
==History==
===Pre–1992=== Before 1992, [[daylight saving time|daylight saving]] was governed by the ''[[Time Act]]'', a law inherited by Israel from the [[British Mandate for Palestine (legal instrument)|British Mandate of Palestine]], which started to use daylight saving in [[World War II]].<ref>{{Cite news|url = http://jpress.org.il/Olive/APA/NLI_Heb/SharedView.Article.aspx?parm=83qIZusvtXYYxP7f2arP59ARtsJmc2LVsBPnAjP0JYnyMMohxQewtfVtBWfTIUX6Yw%3D%3D|script-title=he:״שעון קיץ״|last = Tversky|first = Joshua|date = 6 April 1943|work = 'HaTzofe'|accessdate = 25 August 2014|language = Hebrew|trans-title="Summer clock"}}</ref> Summer Time was introduced in Israel between the years 1948–1957, but the length of Daylight Saving Time has changed significantly depending on the year. In 1951–1952, it was enacted for about seven months, whereas in the years 1953–1954 it was enacted for only three months. In 1958, daylight saving time was canceled. Due to the [[1973 oil crisis|global energy crisis]] because of the aftermath of the [[Yom Kippur War]], Summer Time was enacted again from 1974–1975.
Up until 1992, daylight saving time was operated by an order of the [[Internal Affairs Minister of Israel|minister of the interior]]. In 1980 the authority of the minister for this matter was contested in an appeal to the supreme court. The supreme court decided that the minister's authority was indeed more limited than the common practice, as he may only decide on the dates of IDT while its operation is unquestionable. Following this decision the Knesset amended the Time Act so the minister will also have the authority to abolish IDT in a certain year.
===1992–2005=== The ''Law Determining the Time'' ({{lang-he|חוק קביעת הזמן}} ''{{transl|he|Hok Kvi'at Hazman}}'') is an [[Israel]] law governing Israeli [[daylight saving time]]. It was approved by the [[Knesset]] in 1992, replacing the [[British Mandate for Palestine (legal instrument)|British Mandate of Palestine]] time act inherited by Israel. The 1992 time zone law cancelled the Time Act, and stipulated that IDT will be operated for at least 150 days each year, and that the final dates will be decided by the minister of the Interior, subject to the approval of the Knesset committee for internal affairs. In some years the decision as to which day summer time would start or end was made at the very last minute due to political haggling and this caused disruption to international airline schedules at [[Ben Gurion Airport]].{{cn|date=December 2016}} A tragicomical demonstration of the uncertainty around IDT was in 1999 when two [[Palestinians|Palestinian]] car bombs exploded one hour too early, killing only the bombers themselves.<ref>[http://www.darwinawards.com/darwin/darwin1999-38.html]</ref>
This schedule was variable: the only requirement was that there be at least 150 days per year of IDT, and the dates were set out each year by the Ministry of the Interior.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://webexhibits.org/daylightsaving/g.html#i |title=Daylight Saving Time in Middle East |publisher=Webexhibits.org |date= |accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref>{{dubious|date=October 2011}}
===2005–2012=== Until 2005, the start and end of IDT each year was established in an ad hoc fashion as the result of haggling between political parties representing various sectors of Israeli society. Parties representing religious groups wanted the start delayed till after [[Passover]] and the end to precede [[Yom Kippur]], the Day of Atonement, while the secular parties would argue for starting it earlier and ending it later. Thus, there was no established rule that could guarantee a predictable changeover in either direction. The debates about a fixed rule for determining the dates of IDT went on for years, and resulted in a suggestion that IDT will start on the 2nd day of Passover and end on the weekend between [[Rosh Hashanah]] and Yom Kippur. This suggestion was rejected as it stipulated an annual IDT period of only 5 months, and yet it served as the basis of the final compromise. After 2005, the annual debate has been effectively ended.
In the past, the unpredictability of IDT in Israel became frustrating enough that [[Microsoft Windows]] stopped trying to track changes and just made Israeli time be [[Greenwich Mean Time]] plus two hours (GMT+2) (and disabled the daylight saving option). This has led to various ad hoc solutions to the problem in Windows systems and other Microsoft software (e.g. [[Microsoft Outlook|Outlook]] calendar entries are often off by an hour when shared, due to the lack of IDT support). On November 17, 2009, Microsoft released an update that has daylight saving time enabled for Israel. However, the date for transition back to Standard Time is set as the Second Sunday of September, regardless of the Hebrew Calendar date.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://support.microsoft.com/KB/976098 |title=December 2009 cumulative time zone update for Microsoft Windows operating systems |publisher=Support.microsoft.com |date=2011-06-29 |accessdate=2011-09-06}}</ref> [[Windows 7]] does contain correct IDT times up to 2023, but not all software makes use of this extra information.
In 2010, due to an unusually large difference between the lunar based Hebrew calendar and the solar calendar the date of the return to winter time was September 12, which was very early. This sparked protests by the more secular public, and calls for a change in the way the date is determined. Many members of the government were sympathetic to this and at one point in the ensuing row the Minister even proposed moving to winter time just for [[Yom Kippur]], the Day of Atonement and then returning to summer time. In September 2010 the argument over the dates for summer time reached new heights and some firms even refused to adopt it.<ref>{{cite web|last=Grimland |first=Guy |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/high-tech-firms-refuse-clock-switch-until-late-october-1.313456 |title=High-tech firms refuse clock switch until late October - Haaretz Daily Newspaper | Israel News |publisher=Haaretz.com |date= |accessdate=2011-09-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Service |first=Haaretz |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/dalia-itzik-to-rabbis-find-a-solution-to-daylight-saving-time-crisis-1.312356?localLinksEnabled=false |title=Dalia Itzik to rabbis: Find a solution to daylight saving time crisis - Haaretz Daily Newspaper | Israel News |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=2010-08-09 |accessdate=2011-09-06}}</ref>
On 6 June 2011, Internal Affairs Minister [[Eli Yishai]] announced his support for extending IDT, setting the ending time to the beginning of October. The change required the approval of the Knesset.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/israel-to-get-a-longer-summer-1.366267 |title=Israel to get a longer summer |first=Jonathan |last=Lis |work=Haaretz |date=6 June 2011 |accessdate=2011-06-06}}</ref>
===2013–Present=== On November 5, 2012, the Israeli Knesset approved the bill to extend IDT to a period of 193 days, beginning on the Friday before the last Sunday in March (at 2:00 local time, or 0:00 UTC, clocks are moved forward by one hour), and ending on the first Sunday after October 1 (at 2:00 IDT or 23:00 UTC Saturday, clocks are moved back by one hour).
If the end of IDT falls on Rosh Hashana, the Jewish New Year, then IDT will end on the first Monday after October 1.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timeanddate.com/news/time/israel-dst-extend-2013.html|title=DST in Israel to be extended in 2013|work=timeanddate.com |date=5 November 2012 |accessdate=2012-11-07}}</ref>
On July 8, 2013, the Israeli Knesset approved the bill to extend IDT even further. According to the bill, IDT will begin on the Friday before the last Sunday of March, and end on the last Sunday of October.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.jpost.com/Diplomacy-and-Politics/Knesset-votes-to-extend-Daylight-Saving-Time-319157|title=Knesset votes to extend Daylight Saving Time|work=jpost.com |date=8 July 2013 |accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref>
==Summer Time Dates== {|class=wikitable |- !colspan=4|<big>Summer Time</big> |- !Year !Summer Time Begins !Summer Time Ends !Total Days |- | 2014 | March 28 | October 26 | 212 |- | 2015 | March 27 | October 25 | 212 |- | 2016 | March 25 | October 30 | 219 |- | 2017 | March 24 | October 29 | 219 |- | 2018 | March 23 | October 28 | 219 |- | 2019 | March 29 | October 27 | 212 |- | 2020 | March 27 | October 25 | 212 |}
==See also== *[[Israel Standard Time]] *[[Eastern European Time]] (EET) *[[Eastern European Summer Time]] (EEST)
== References == {{reflist}}

{{Infobox academic | honorific_prefix = <!-- see [[MOS:HONOURIFIC]] --> | name = James Morris Blaut | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = <!-- use only if different from full/othernames --> | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | death_cause = | region = | nationality = American | citizenship = | residence = | other_names = | occupation = | period = | known_for = Anti-[[Eurocentrism]] | title = | boards = <!--board or similar positions extraneous to main occupation--> | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | awards = <!--notable national level awards only--> | website = | education = | alma_mater = [[University of Chicago]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | school_tradition = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | influences = <!--must be referenced from a third party source--> | era = | discipline = [[Geography]] | sub_discipline = <!--academic discipline specialist area – e.g. Sub-atomic research, 20th Century Danish specialist, Pauline research, Arcadian and Ugaritic specialist--> | workplaces = <!--full-time positions only, not student positions--> | doctoral_students = <!--only those with WP articles--> | notable_students = <!--only those with WP articles--> | main_interests = | notable_works = | notable_ideas = | influenced = <!--must be referenced from a third party source--> | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | footnotes = }}
'''James Morris Blaut''' (October 20, 1927 – November 11, 2000), also known as '''J. M. Blaut''', was a professor of anthropology and geography at the [[University of Illinois at Chicago]]. His studies focused on the agricultural [[microgeography]] (geographical activity of villagers), cultural ecology, theory of [[nationalism]], philosophy of science, historiography and the relations between the [[First World|First]] and the [[Third World]]. He is known as one of the most notable critics of [[Eurocentrism]]. Blaut was one of the most widely read authors in the field of geography.<ref name=kmds>Kent Mathewson; David Stea, [http://www.marxmail.org/BlautMemorial.pdf ''In memoriam: James M. Blaut (1927–2000)''] ''Annals of the Association of American Geographers'', 93(1), 2003, pp. 214–222</ref>
==Life and career== James Morris Blaut was born on October 20, 1927 in [[New York City]].<ref name=kmds/> He attended the [[Little Red School House]] and [[Elisabeth Irwin High School]].<ref name=kmds/> He entered the [[University of Chicago]] in 1944 at the age of sixteen, as part of the program for advanced high-school students, and achieved two bachelor's degrees (in 1948 and 1950).<ref name=kmds/> Next, from 1948 to 1949, he studied in the [[New School for Social Research]], from 1949 to 1950 at the [[Imperial College of Tropical Agriculture]] in [[Trinidad]], and from 1950 at [[Louisiana State University]].<ref name=kmds/> After the end of the [[Korean War]], he also served in the [[US Army]], and was involved in an incident which resulted in [[court-martial]] of his commander and the dismissal of the camp’s commandant.<ref name=kmds/>
He received his PhD in 1958, at which time he was already working at the [[Yale University]].<ref name=kmds/> In 1960 he moved to [[University of Puerto Rico]], where he stayed till 1963.<ref name=kmds/> In 1964 he moved to the [[College of the Virgin Islands]]. In 1967 he returned to the United States for a position at [[Clark University]], where in 1969 he helped establish the ''[[Antipode (journal)|Antipode Journal]]'' and the [[Union of Socialist Geographers]].<ref name=kmds/> In 1971, told that his activities and ideas were too extreme for Clark, he moved back to the [[University of Puerto Rico]], and finally to [[University of Illinois at Chicago]].<ref name=kmds/>
Blaut's death in 2000 prevented him from finishing his trilogy of books criticizing Eurocentric theories of a "[[European miracle]]". (It begins with ''The Colonizer’s Model of the World'' and is followed by the ''Eight Eurocentric Historians'').<ref name=kmds/>
He was a member and activist of [[Henry A. Wallace]]’s [[Progressive Party (United States, 1948)|Progressive Party]]. He supported a variety of activists' campaigns during the [[Vietnam War]].<ref name=kmds/> He was also a supporter of the [[Puerto Rican independence movement]].<ref name=kmds/>
==Legacy and honors== Blaut received several awards for distinguished service and scholarship, such as the [[Association of American Geographers]]'s Distinguished Scholarship Award in 1997.
The Cultural and Political Ecology Study Group of the Association of American Geographers issues the annual [http://www2.stetson.edu/cape/Honors/honors.htm James M. Blaut Award] in recognition of innovative scholarship in cultural and political ecology. The Socialist and Critical Geography Specialty Group of the AAG also issues a James Blaut Award and has a Memorial Lecture.
In his private life, his hobbies included [[bird watching]].<ref name=kmds/>
==Publications== *1987 – ''The National Question: Decolonising the Theory of Nationalism'' (London: [[Zed Books]]) *1992 – ''Fourteen Ninety-Two: The Debate on Colonialism, Eurocentrism and History'' (with contributions by S. Amin, R. Dodgshon, A. G. Frank, and R. Palan; Trenton, NJ: AfricaWorld Press) *1993 – ''The Colonizer’s Model of the World: Geographical Diffusionism and Eurocentric History'' (NY: Guilford Press) *2000 – ''Eight Eurocentric Historians'' (NY: Guilford Press)
==See also == *[[Andre Gunder Frank]] *[[Samir Amin]] *[[Angus Maddison]] *[[John M. Hobson]]
==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist}}
'''Further reading''' *Kent Mathewson, "James Morris Blaut (1927–2000)," pp. 107–130 in H. Lorimer and C.W.J. Withers, editors, ''Geographers: Biobibliographical Studies'', 27 (New York: Continuum, 2008).
==External links== *[http://www.columbia.edu/~lnp3/mydocs/blaut.htm James M. Blaut Page] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060518055147/http://archives.econ.utah.edu/archives/marxism/2004w39/msg00120.htm Tributes to Jim Blaut], Marxism mailing list archive * [https://lsu.academia.edu/KMathewson/Papers/175256/The_Geographical_and_Political_Vision_of_J._M._Blaut_-_Special_Issue_of_Antipode_Vol._35_No._5_pp._900-1050_co-edited_with_B._Wisner_ The Geographical and Political Vision of J. M. Blaut]. Special Issue of ''[[Antipode (journal)|Antipode]]'', vol. 35, n° 5, pp. 900–1050 (co-edited with B. Wisner) by Kent Mathewson, 2005.

'''João de Trasto''' is the name sometimes given to an obscure (and possibly fictional) [[Kingdom of Portugal|Portuguese]] mariner, who is alleged to have captained the first [[exploration|exploratory]] expedition dispatched by Prince [[Henry the Navigator]] in 1415.
The only record of João de Trasto or the 1415 expedition is a brief mention in the personal memoirs of [[Diogo Gomes]], a former Henrican captain.<ref>Diogo Gomes "De prima inventione Guineae", as first published in 1847, in J.A. Schmeller, ''Abhandlungen der Philosophisch-Philologischen Classe der Königlich Bayerischen Akademie der Wissenschaften'', Munich, Vol. 4 (3), [https://books.google.com/books?id=-EREAAAAcAAJ&pg=RA3-PA19#v=onepage&q&f=false p.19].</ref> According to Gomes, "Johannes de Trasto" commanded an expedition in 1415, dispatched by Henry the Navigator. Probably departing from the port of [[Lagos, Portugal|Lagos]], the Trasto expedition was forced by foul weather to the part of the [[Grand Canary]] island subsequently called ''Telli''. Returning to Portugal, he again encountered a fierce [[storm]] and only with great difficulty arrived in [[port]].<ref>R.H. Major (1868: [https://books.google.com/books?id=x249AAAAYAAJ&pg=PA64#v=onepage&q&f=false p.64-65])</ref>
The writer Diogo Gomes was not an eyewitness to the event (Gomes was not born until the 1420s) and his memoirs were dictated many decades later, at the end of his life, c.1490s, and are known to contain numerous small errors of dates and facts. As the historian R.H. Major writes, after retelling the Trasto story in his 1868 edition, "there is however so much that is manifestly inaccurate in other statements of Diego Gomes respecting the early voyages which he narrates from hearsay, that we cannot be perfectly sure that the date here applied to the earliest expedition is correct."<ref>Major (1868: p.65). For more on the unreliability of Diogo Gomes's memoirs, see Russell (2000: p.328-29).</ref> In later editions of his work, Major removed all mention of "João de Trasto".<ref>e.g. R.H. Major (1877). Any such passage would have come after [https://books.google.com/books?id=VrkEAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA53#v=onepage&q&f=false p.53].</ref>
As a result, most historians have doubted the existence of 'João de Trasto' and this expedition. It is usually omitted in modern scholarly histories of the [[Portuguese discoveries]].<ref>e.g. Diffie and Winius (1973), Russell (2000).</ref>
Some historians have suggested that Diogo Gomes probably meant to refer to D. [[Fernando de Castro]], who is indeed recorded to have led a failed expedition to [[Gran Canaria]] for Henry the Navigator in 1424.<ref>Arruda (1932: lxiv); Peres (1943: p.46); Cortesão (1969: p.95)</ref> Indeed, it seems "Trasto" is a mistranscription in the first (1847) printed edition of Diogo Gomes's letter, that the original manuscript actually read "Crasto" (probably meaning "Castro").<ref>Gabriel Pereira, 1899, ''Boletim da Sociedade de Geographia de Lisboa'', ([https://books.google.com/books?id=-USdAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA264-IA5#v=onepage&q&f=false p.264], 270). This reading is adhered to by later historians, e.g. Peres, Cortesão, Diffie & Winius, etc.</ref> Castro did have a brother named João, and that might have been the source of confusion,<ref>Diffie & Winius (1973: p.58). João de Castro is briefly mentioned fighting alongside his brother Fernando de Castro in [[Gomes Eanes de Zurara]]'s account of the [[battle of Ceuta]] (Ch. 86), but he is nowhere to be found in Zurara's chronicle of the discoveries.</ref> or alternatively, Gomes's interpreter or transcriber simply misheard "João" for "Fernão".
==Notes==
{{Reflist}}

London: Asher & Co. * Major, Richard Henry (1877) ''Discoveries of Prince Henry the Navigator'', London: S. Low, Marston, Searle, & Rivington. * Peres, Damião (1943) ''História dos descobrimentos portugueses'', Porto: Portucalense. * Russell, Peter E. (2000) ''Prince Henry 'the Navigator': a life''. New Haven, Conn: Yale University Press. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Trasto, Joao De}} [[Category:15th-century explorers of Africa]] [[Category:Nautical captains]] [[Category:Medieval Portuguese nobility]] [[Category:Portuguese explorers]] [[Category:Age of Discovery]] [[Category:15th-century Portuguese people]] [[Category:Maritime history of Portugal]]

'''Khandesh''' ([[Marathi language|Marathi]]:खानदेश) is a geographic region in [[Central India]], which forms the northwestern portion of [[Maharashtra]] state.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.khandesh.com/info/ |title=Welcome to Khandesh! |publisher=Khandesh.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-01}}</ref>
== Geography == Khandesh lies in [[Central India]] on the northwestern corner of the [[Deccan Plateau]], in the valley of the [[Tapti River|Tapi River]]. It is bounded to the north by the [[Satpura Range]], to the east by the [[Berar Division|Berar]] ([[Vidarbha]]) region, to the south by the Hills of Ajanta (belonging to the Marathwada region of Maharashtra), and to the west by the northernmost ranges of the [[Western Ghats]].
The principal natural feature is the [[Tapi River, India|Tapi River]].<ref name=":2" /> Unlike the rest of the Deccan, whose rivers rise in the Western Ghats and flow eastward to the [[Bay of Bengal]], the Tapi flows westward from headwaters in southern Madhya Pradesh to empty into the [[Arabian Sea]]. The Tapi receives thirteen principal tributaries in its course through Khandesh. None of these rivers is navigable, and the Tapi flows in a deep bed which historically made it difficult to use for irrigation. Most of Khandesh lies south of the Tapi and is drained by its tributaries: the [[Girna River|Girna]], [[Bori River|Bori]] and [[Panzara|Panjhra]]. The alluvial plain north of the Tapi contains some of the richest tracts in Khandesh, and the land rises towards the Satpuda hills. In the centre and east, the country is level, save for some low ranges of barren hills. To the north and west, the plain rises into rugged hills, thickly wooded, and inhabited by the tribal [[Bhil]] people.
== History ==
=== Delhi dynasties === In 1295, Khandesh was under the [[Chauhan]] ruler of Asirgarh when [[Ala-ud-din Khilji]] of Delhi wrested control.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001869096|title=Imperial Gazetteer of India|last=|first=|publisher=Superintendent of Government Printing|year=1909|isbn=|volume=Provincial Series: Bombay Presidency Vol. 1|location=Calcutta|pages=}}</ref>{{Rp|418}} Various Delhi dynasties controlled Khandesh over the next century.<ref name=":1" />{{Rp|418}} From 1370 to 1600, the [[Faruqi dynasty]] ruled Khandesh with the capital at [[Burhanpur]].<ref name=":1" />{{Rp|418}} The foundation of Khandesh as an independent kingdom was laid by Malik Raja, son of Khanjahan Faurki. [[Firuz Shah Tughlaq]] had initially appointed Malik Raja as the commander-in-chief of Khandesh region, but he declares himself independent after the death of Firoz Tughlaq and ruled until 1399.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Historical Atlas|last=Goyal|first=S. P.|publisher=Upkar|isbn=978-81-7482-752-4|location=Agra|pages=68}}</ref>
=== Mughal rule === The [[Mughal Empire|Mughals]] arrived in 1599, when Akbar's army overran Khandesh and captured [[Asirgarh Fort|Asirgarh]].<ref name=":1" />{{Rp|418}} For a period of time, Khandesh was renamed as Dandesh in recognition of Akbar's son [[Daniyal Mirza|Daniyal]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rbUBAAAAYAAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=Gazetteer of the Bombay Presidency|last=|first=|publisher=Government Central Press|year=1880|isbn=|volume=Volume XII: Khandesh|location=Bombay|pages=}}</ref>[[Daniyal|{{Rp|248}}]] {{circa|1640}}, [[Todar Mal]]'s revenue settlement system was introduced in Khandesh by [[Shah Jahan]] (this system was used until British rule in 1818).<ref name=":0" />{{Rp|250}} The mid-17th century has been described as the time of Khandesh's "highest prosperity" owing to trade in cotton, rice, indigo, sugarcane, and cloth.<ref name=":0" />{{Rp|250}} Mughal rule lasted until the [[Maratha Empire|Marathas]] captured Asirgarh in 1760.<ref name=":1" />{{Rp|418}}
=== Maratha rule === Maratha raids into Khandesh began in 1670 and the following century was a period of unrest as Mughals and Marathas competed for control.<ref name=":1" />{{Rp|418}} In 1760, the [[Peshwa]] ousted the Mughal ruler and gained control of Khandesh, following which portions were granted to [[Holkar]] and [[Scindia]] rulers.<ref name=":1" />{{Rp|418}} [[Baji Rao II]] surrendered to the British in June 1818, but sporadic war continued in Khandesh which was among the last of the Peshwa's former territories to come under complete [[British Raj|British control]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=79sS_w_bOQYC&source=gbs_navlinks_s|title=John Briggs in Maharashtra: A Study of District Administration Under Early British Rule|last=Deshpande|first=Arvind M.|publisher=Mittal Publications|year=1987|isbn=|location=Delhi|pages=}}</ref>{{Rp|9}}
=== British rule === [[File:KhandeshDistrict-1878.png|thumb|Khandesh District (1878)]] Khandesh was a district in the [[Bombay Presidency]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://storage.lib.uchicago.edu/pres/2014/pres2014-0779-1911-07-01.pdf|title=Census of India, 1911|last=|first=|publisher=Government Central Press|year=1912|isbn=|volume=Volume VII, Bombay: Part 1, Report|location=Bombay|pages=1}}</ref> In 1906, the district was divided into two districts: East Khandesh, headquartered at [[Jalgaon]], had an area of {{convert|4544|sqmi|abbr=on|order=flip}}, while West Khandesh, headquartered at [[Dhule]], had an area of {{convert|5497|sqmi|abbr=on|order=flip}}; their respective populations were 957,728 and 469,654 in 1901.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.khandesh.com/info/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=46:khandesh-information&catid=29:overview&Itemid=37 |title=Khandesh |publisher=Khandesh |date= |accessdate=2010-08-01}}</ref>
=== Independent India === After India's independence in 1947, Bombay province became [[Bombay State]], and in 1960 was divided into the linguistic states of [[Maharashtra]] and [[Gujarat]]. East Khandesh became [[Jalgaon district]], and West Khandesh became Dhule district, both in Maharashtra state.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Commercial Activities and Rural Development in South Asia: A Geographical Study|last=Jamkar|first=A.G.|publisher=Concept Publishing Company|year=1988|isbn=81-7022-194-3|editor-last=Shrivastava|editor-first=V.K.|location=New Delhi|pages=134|chapter=Origin and Evolution of Periodic Market Places in Dhule District (Maharashtra)}}</ref> The latter was further divided into [[Dhule district|Dhule]] and [[Nandurbar district]]s.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=http://hdl.handle.net/10603/136532|title=An Inventory on Agrobiodiversity and Homestead Gardens in Tribal Tehsils of Khandesh Maharashtra|last=Patil|first=M.V.|publisher=North Maharashtra University|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=Chapter 6-1}}</ref>
== Culture == Khandesh has a rich cultural and literary heritage.
=== Languages === [[Marathi language|Marathi]] is the official and most-spoken language in Khandesh. [[Ahirani]] and [[Gujari]] are spoken in the Girana basin of West Khandesh; these languages are dialects of Marathi with Gujarati and Hindi influence. [[Khandeshi language|Khandeshi]] is spoken in the eastern part of Khandesh.<ref>{{cite web|author=Santronix Computers pvt. Ltd. |url=http://ejalgaon.com/jalgaoninfo/khandesh%20cultural%20heritage.html |title=Khandesh cultural heritage - Jalgaon, Dhule, Nandurbar lifestyle |publisher=Ejalgaon.com |date=2007-05-19 |accessdate=2010-08-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820220633/http://ejalgaon.com/jalgaoninfo/khandesh%20cultural%20heritage.html |archivedate=20 August 2010 |df= }}</ref> [[Dakhini]] is also spoken there.
=== Arts === {{example farm|section|this is just a list of notable people in the arts, it says nothing about the arts in the region|date=October 2018}} [[File:Shev Bhaaji.JPG|thumb|Shev [[Bhaaji]], a typical Khandesh dish]] In the 13th century, Mukta Bai, the younger sister of Dnyaneshwar, lived at Muktainagar, near where the great yogi Changdeva lived. There was also a strong presence of Kabir Panth in Khandesh due to the proximity of [[Burhanpur]], the seat of Kabir Panth.
[[Bahinabai Chaudhari]], regarded as one of the greatest female poets in Marathi literature, belonged to a Khandeshi family. Her son, Kavi Sopandeo Choudhary, was also a well-known poet. Trambak Bapuji Thombre, commonly known as [[Balkavi]], is from Jalgaon. Dr. V.B. Kolte, a noted scholar of Marathi, hailed from Khandesh; he was the top authority on Mahanubhav literature.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}}
Well known Marathi writers from Khandesh region, include Dr. Bhalchandra Nemade, [[N. D. Mahanor]], Dr. T. T. Mahajan and Dr. Sharad Rane.

page.title: Line of succession to the Tongan throne

revision.text:
The '''order of succession''' to the throne of [[Tonga]] is laid down in the 1875 constitution. The crown descends according to [[male-preference cognatic primogeniture]]. Only legitimate descendants through legitimate line of King [[George Tupou I]]'s son and grandson, Crown Prince [[Tēvita ʻUnga]] and Prince [[ʻUelingatoni Ngū]], are entitled to succeed. A person loses his or her right of succession and deprives his or her descendants of their right of succession if he or she marries without the monarch's permission.
== Line of succession ==
The current line of succession is as follows:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pmo.gov.to/state-funeral/the-monarchy/3539-succession-to-the-tongan-throne|title=Succession to the Tongan Throne|publisher=Tonga Government Portal|date=2012-03-22|accessdate=2012-06-25}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
{{Tree list}} *[[Image:Simple silver crown.svg|15px]] ''[[Tāufaʻāhau Tupou IV|HM King Tupou IV]] (1918–2006)'' ** [[Image:Simple silver crown.svg|15px]] ''[[George Tupou V|HM King Tupou V]] (1948–2012)'' ** The Hon. Ma’atu (1954–2004, removed from the line of succession in 1980) *** HSH The Prince Tungi (b. 1990) *** The Hon. Fatafehi Sione Ikamafana Ta’anekinga ‘o Tonga Tuita (b. 1994) *** The Hon. ‘Etani Ha’amea Tupoulahi Tu’uakitau Ui Tu’alangi Tuku’aho (b. 1995) ***{{Tree list/final branch}} The Hon. Salote Maumautaimi Haim Hadessah Ber Yardena ‘Alanuanua Tuku’aho (b. 1991) **[[Image:Simple gold crown.svg|15px]] '''[[Tupou VI|HM King Tupou VI]]''' (born 1959) *** '''(1)''' [[Tupoutoʻa ʻUlukalala|HRH The Crown Prince]] (b. 1985) **** '''(2)''' [[Taufaʻahau Manumataongo|HRH Prince Taufaʻahau Manumataongo]]<ref>[http://matangitonga.to/2013/05/10/new-tongan-heir-prince-taufaahau-manumataongo-born-may-10-auckland "New Tongan heir, Prince Taufa'ahau Manumataongo born May 10 in Auckland"], [[Matangi Tonga]]</ref> (b. 2013) HRH the Princess Nanasipau'u ****{{Tree list/final branch}} '''(3)''' HRH Princess Halaevalu Mata'aho<ref>[http://matangitonga.to/2014/07/14/tongas-new-princess-halaevalu-mataaho "Tonga's New Princess: Halaevalu Mata'aho"], [[Matangi Tonga]], 14 July 2014</ref> (b. 2014) ****{{Tree list/final branch}} '''(4)''' HRH Princess Nanasipau’u, 20 March 2018 *** '''(5)''' [[Prince Ata|HRH The Prince Ata]] (b. 1988) ***{{Tree list/final branch}} '''(6)''' [[Princess Lātūfuipeka Tukuʻaho|HRH Princess Angelika Lātūfuipeka Tukuʻaho]] (b. 1983) **{{Tree list/final branch}} '''(7)''' [[Salote Mafile'o Pilolevu Tuita|HRH Princess Salote Mafile'o Pilolevu Tuita, Lady Tuita]] (b. 1951) *** '''(8)''' Hon. Sālote Lupepau'u Salamasina Purea Vahine Arii 'Oe Hau Tuita (b. 1977) **** {{Tree list/final branch}}'''(9)''' Hon. Phaedra Anaseini Tupouveihola Ikaleti Olo-'i-Fangatapu Fusituʻa (b. 2003) *** '''(10)''' Hon. Titilupe Fanetupouvava'u Tuita Tu'ivakano (b. 1978) **** '''(11)''' Hon. Simon Tu'iha'atu'unga George Ma'ulupekotofa Tu'ivakano (b. 2011) **** '''(12)''' Hon. Michaela Tu'ivakano (b. 2012) ****{{Tree list/final branch}} '''(13)''' Hon. Fatafehi Tu'ivakano (b. 2013) *** '''(14)''' Hon. Frederica Lupe'uluiva Fatafehi 'o Lapaha Tuita Filipe (b. 1983) ****{{Tree list/final branch}} '''(15)''' Hon. Latu'alaifotu'aika Fahina e Paepae Tian Tian Filipe (b. 2014) *** {{Tree list/final branch}} '''(16)''' Hon. Lupeolo Halaevalu Moheofo Virginia Rose Tuita (b. 1986) {{Tree list/end}}

revision.comment: a) ref is a dead link and b) article says nothig about it being an Xmas food
revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=May 2008}} [[File:Oven roasted brine-soaked turkey.jpg|thumb|right|250px|An oven-roasted [[Brining|brine-soaked]] turkey]]
[[File:Traditional fruitcake.jpg|250px|thumb|[[Fruit cake]]]]
This page is a '''list of Christmas dishes''' as eaten around the world. These food items are traditionally eaten at or associated with the [[Christmas]] season.
== Albania ==
*Byrek me kungull dhe arre – This is a traditional Albanian pumpkin and walnut pie cooked usually on Christmas Eve, especially in Catholic families. The ingredients are wheat flour, pumpkin, walnuts, vegetable oil (if fasting is considered) or butter, a pinch of salt and black pepper. Sometimes oregano is added. The pastry layers are traditionally homemade, filled with baked pumpkin mixture, which contains butter, salt and pepper. On top of the mixture, chopped walnuts are sprinkled. Layers are then folded up, put on a flat baking dish in a circular shape and baked. It makes a very delicious and light side dish for Christmas or any other occasion.
== Argentina == {{see also|Argentine cuisine}} [[File:Vitello tonnato.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Vitello tonnato]] is a very popular Christmas dish in Argentina, where it is known as vitel toné. The [[Piedmont]]ese dish is valued during the summer for its cold serving temperature, and is the legacy of the large [[Italian Argentines|Italian immigration]] to the country.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://entremujeres.clarin.com/entremujeres/rincon-gourmet/vitel_tone-las_fiestas-navidad-ano_nuevo-mesa_navidena-recetas-rincon_gourmet_0_BJtuP9FwQg.html |title=Vitel toné: la receta de un clásico para las Fiestas |language=Spanish |last1=Fumarola|first1=Leonardo |last2= |first2= |date=December 17, 2015 |work= |publisher=Clarín.com |accessdate=June 1, 2017}}</ref>]] [[Panettone]] (known locally as ''pan dulce'') and [[turrón]] are the most popular Christmas sweets in Argentina regardless of [[socioeconomic status]], with 76% of Argentines choosing the former and 59% the latter in 2015.<ref name="elcronista"/> [[Mantecol]], a typical peanut dessert, is also popular, being favored by 49% of Argentines in the same survey.<ref name="kantar">{{cite web|url=https://www.kantarworldpanel.com/ar/Noticias/Que-dulces-no-pueden-faltar-en-estas-fiestas|title=¿Qué dulces no pueden faltar en estas fiestas?|date=December 23, 2016|publisher=Kantar Worldpanel|access-date=June 1, 2017|language=Spanish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171018190700/https://www.kantarworldpanel.com/ar/Noticias/Que-dulces-no-pueden-faltar-en-estas-fiestas|archivedate=October 18, 2017|df=}}</ref> [[Sparkling wine]]s, [[cider]]s and [[frizzante]]s concentrate most of their sales during Christmas season; sparkling wine is mostly consumed by small families with high and medium socioeconomic status living in [[Greater Buenos Aires]] and [[The New York Times|the]] country's largest cities, while cider and frizzantes are popular among lower classes and large families.<ref name="kantar"/>

== Australia == [[File:Candy-Cane-Classic.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Candy Cane]] can be hung as edible decorations.]] * [[White Christmas (food)|White Christmas]], a sweet slice made of [[copha]] and mixed fruit * Cold [[ham]] and cold [[Turkey (food)|turkey]]<ref name="CultRecAu" /> * [[Seafood]] and [[salad]]s<ref name="CultRecAu" /> * [[Roasting|Roast]] [[Chicken (food)|chicken]], ham and turkey<ref name="CultRecAu">{{cite web|url=http://www.cultureandrecreation.gov.au/articles/christmas/ |title=Christmas season celebrations in Australia |accessdate=2007-03-12 |publisher=Culture and Recreation.gov.au |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110408180134/http://www.cultureandrecreation.gov.au/articles/christmas/ |archivedate=2011-04-08 |df= }}</ref> * [[Stuffing]]<ref name="Santa recipe Australia">{{cite web |url=http://www.santas.net/recipes.htm |title=Santa's Net: Recipes |publisher=Santas.net |accessdate=24 December 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111228071953/http://www.santas.net/recipes.htm |archivedate=28 December 2011 |df= }}</ref> * [[Christmas cake]] or [[Christmas pudding]]<ref name="CultRecAu"/> * [[Custard]] * [[Gingerbread]] in Christmas shapes * Christmas [[damper (food)|damper]] - in [[wreath]] or star shape, served with [[butter]], [[jam]], [[honey]] or [[golden syrup]]. Made in the [[Australian bush]] in the 19th century.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.santas.net/christmasdamper.htm |title=Christmas Damper from Australia |publisher=Santas.net |accessdate=24 December 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111129115620/http://www.santas.net/christmasdamper.htm |archivedate=29 November 2011 |df= }}</ref> * [[Confectionery|lollies]], such as [[rocky road (dessert)|rocky road]]; [[rum ball]]s; [[candy cane]]s * [[Champagne (wine)|Champagne]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://latrobetimes.blogs.latrobe.edu.au/2015/01/15/typical-aussie-christmas-top-5-things-you-didnt-know/|title=Typical Aussie Christmas - top 5 things you didn't know- La Trobe University international news|date=15 January 2015|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170316024642/https://latrobetimes.blogs.latrobe.edu.au/2015/01/15/typical-aussie-christmas-top-5-things-you-didnt-know/|archivedate=16 March 2017|df=}}</ref> * [[Eggnog]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.luvaduck.com.au/recipes/view/egg-nog-for-christmas/43/|title=Recipe for Egg Nog for Christmas There is nothing that makes Christmas feel more special like a glass of egg nog!|website=Luv-a-Duck|accessdate=2 May 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170225095156/http://www.luvaduck.com.au/recipes/view/egg-nog-for-christmas/43/|archivedate=25 February 2017|df=}}</ref> * [[Trifle]] * [[Pavlova (food)|Pavlova]]<ref name="Santa recipe Australia"/> * [[Prawns]] * [[Mince pie]] * Ice cream * Jelly * Fish * Cherries * Lollipops * Fruit platters with apples,cherries,bananas,mangos,coconuts,lychees,pawpaws (papayas),carrot sticks,snow peas,beans,etc. * Potato Salad * Nuts such as peanuts,ground nuts and pinenuts * Doughnuts * Strawberries and other berries * Rice and bean salad * Oysters * Chocolates or Chocolate rolls * Christmas cookies
